reg:regulation.reg:acttitle: Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act
reg:regulation.reg:title: Sled Dog Standards of Care Regulation

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a sled dog's pen, or
the area within which a tethered sled dog may roam;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: dog box means a crate or other container intended for use in transporting a sled dog, but not intended for use as a pen;
dog house means a shelter, provided for one or more sled dogs, that meets the requirements of section 7 [dog house requirements];
pen means a contained area from which a dog is unable to escape, and includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a yard,
a run, and
a cage, kennel or other structure;
if a sled dog is in British Columbia, a registered veterinarian within the meaning of the Act, and

bcl:definition.bcl:text: rehome means to place a former sled dog in the care of another guardian when the dog is no longer used for sled dog activities;
sled dog means a dog kept primarily or used routinely for a sled dog activity;
sled dog activity means the keeping and use of, or the breeding of, a sled dog for dog-powered or load-bearing activity, including pulling

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person on skis or in or on a vehicle or any other mechanism, and
a vehicle or weight,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: whether over snow, on dry land or in another environment;
species-typical behaviours include running, jumping and safe physical contact with other sled dogs;
work means the participation of a sled dog in a sled dog activity, including training and conditioning to participate in a sled dog activity.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Sled dog activities are prescribed as regulated activities for the purposes of the Act.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Keeping and Caring for Sled Dogs

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that each containment area

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: includes a dog house, and
provides sufficient room for each sled dog within the containment area to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: urinate and defecate away from areas commonly used for eating and sleeping.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that each sled dog in a containment area has sufficient opportunities to engage in species-typical behaviours.
An operator must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: clean containment areas of fecal matter at least once each day, and
ensure that containment areas, and any structures or equipment within them, are maintained in a sanitary condition.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Construction and maintenance of pens and tethers
bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that pens and tethers meet all of the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sled dogs must be unable to escape from a pen or tether;
materials used to construct a pen, or from which a tether is made, must be durable;
pens and tethers must be designed and constructed or made so as to prevent sled dogs from injuring themselves;
pens must be free of standing water;
pens and tethers must be maintained in good repair.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that pens are constructed to meet the following minimum space requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if one sled dog is to be kept in the pen, 9.3 m2;
if 2 sled dogs are to be kept in the pen, 13.0 m2;
if more than 2 sled dogs are to be kept in the pen, 13.0 m2 plus sufficient space for each sled dog to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: maintain adequate social distances from other sled dogs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that tethers

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are safe for sled dogs,
are of a size and weight that will not cause discomfort to tethered sled dogs,
are at least 1.83 m long, and
have, at the collar end, at least one swivel that can turn 360°.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must not use a choke collar as part of a tethering method.
An operator must ensure that tethering methods substantially conform to one of the methods illustrated in Schedule A.
An operator must ensure that tethered sled dogs may engage in safe physical contact with other sled dogs, with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the lowest possible risk of tangling, and
no overlap of adjacent tethers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that dog houses provide an enclosed area that is large enough to permit sled dogs to stand, turn around and lie down comfortably.
An operator must ensure that dog houses are constructed and maintained so as to provide

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: shelter from rain, wind, snow, sun and other elements, and
protection from excessive heat and cold.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), an operator must ensure that each sled dog is fed, at least once every 24 hours, a balanced diet that is sufficient to meet the sled dog's caloric and nutritional requirements.
If a registered veterinarian or an expert in canine nutrition gives directions to an operator respecting feeding schedules, the operator must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keep a record of those directions, and
take them into account when determining the sled dog's caloric and nutritional requirements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that each sled dog has access to clean and palatable drinking water, in adequate quantities to meet its needs and prevent dehydration.
An operator must ensure that food and water containers are kept clean and free of contamination.
An operator must ensure that each sled dog is groomed sufficiently to ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the sled dog is free of discomfort from excessive heat, and
the sled dog's coat is free of matting, parasites and coat-related illness or disease.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that the nails of each sled dog are maintained so as to prevent

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: penetration of the skin or foot pads, and
digital displacement.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that each sled dog is socialized throughout its life in a manner that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: minimizes behavioural problems,
includes direct contact with humans and other animals,
includes a variety of stimuli and environments, and
maximizes the chances that the sled dog may be successfully rehomed and thrive in a new environment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that each sled dog

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receives sufficient exercise to maintain its health and well-being, and
is directly supervised when using exercise equipment, including swimming pools and treadmills.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that each sled dog is released from its containment area, at least once in each 24 hour period, for the purposes of socialization and exercise.
Subsection (1) does not apply in any of the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the sled dog should not be moved or released due to illness or injury;
if the sled dog is a female that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is within one week of her anticipated whelping date, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the sled dog is younger than 6 weeks old;
if extreme weather conditions would make it unsafe for the sled dog to be released;
if the sled dog

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has, within the previous 24 hour period, participated in a racing activity or other activity involving significant physical exertion, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a registered veterinarian has given direction that the sled dog not be released.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that the body condition of each sled dog is monitored regularly.
An operator must seek the assistance and direction of a registered veterinarian if the body condition of a sled dog, as determined according to the scale set out in Schedule B, is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: less than 3, or
7 or more.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an operator suspects or becomes aware that a sled dog may be suffering a communicable disease, the operator must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: immediately isolate the sled dog from people and other animals in a manner that will prevent spread of the disease,
regularly supervise the isolated sled dog, and
immediately seek the assistance and direction of a registered veterinarian.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an operator suspects or becomes aware that a sled dog is experiencing severe pain or is suffering deteriorating health or serious injury, the operator must immediately seek the assistance and direction of a registered veterinarian.
For the purposes of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the assistance and direction of a registered veterinarian may be through indirect consultation or direct examination, and
an operator must comply with the directions of the registered veterinarian.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, intact male means a male sled dog that is capable of breeding.
An operator must ensure that each female sled dog that is in heat is separated from all intact males, unless the operator intends to breed the female.
An operator who intends to breed a female sled dog must ensure that the female has access to only one intact male at a time.
An operator must ensure that a sled dog that does not appear willing to work is not dragged or otherwise physically coerced into work.
An operator must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: work does not cause a sled dog to be in distress, and
training and discipline methods do not cause a sled dog to be in fear or distress.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must not work a sled dog if the sled dog is likely to suffer hypothermia, hyperthermia, frostbite, dehydration or other illnesses or injuries related to the environment.
An operator must not work a sled dog that is suffering from illness or injury unless the operator

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: seeks the assistance and direction of a registered veterinarian, and
complies with the directions of the registered veterinarian.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must not permit a sled dog to be administered a drug of any kind, including analgesics and anti-inflammatories, for the purpose of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enhancing the work performance of the sled dog, or
working the sled dog beyond its natural abilities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that all equipment that may come into contact with a working sled dog, including harnesses and collars, is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fitted properly so as not to cause discomfort, injury or difficulty breathing,
clean, and
in good repair.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must not use a choke collar while working a sled dog.
An operator must carry, at all times while working sled dogs, an appropriate tool for use in cutting and removing lines or other equipment in an emergency.
Subject to subsection (2), an operator must not permit a sled dog to be transported if the sled dog

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is displaying any sign of shock, exhaustion, fever, dehydration or an injury or illness that is more than trivial in nature,
is a female that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is within one week of her anticipated whelping date, or
has whelped within 2 weeks before the date of transport.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of a sled dog being transported for the purposes of receiving the assistance of a registered veterinarian.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that dog boxes are adequately ventilated and are constructed and maintained to meet the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a sled dog must be able to stand, turn around and lie down comfortably within a dog box;
a sled dog must be unable to escape from a dog box;
materials used to construct dog boxes must be durable;
dog boxes must be maintained in good repair;
dog boxes must be securely attached to the transport vehicle.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that a transported sled dog arrives at its destination in a sanitary condition, comfortable and not in distress.
An operator must ensure that, during transport, a sled dog is removed from its dog box regularly for the purpose of feeding, watering and elimination.
An operator must not permit a sled dog to be killed unless the operator

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: reasonably believes that the sled dog is in critical distress within the meaning of section 12 (1) of the Act, or
has made reasonable efforts to rehome the sled dog, but those efforts have been unsuccessful.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must keep a record of the following, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the reason for the belief described in subsection (1) (a);
the efforts that have been made under subsection (1) (b), including why those efforts were not successful.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not kill a sled dog unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a registered veterinarian, the registered veterinarian does so in accordance with the standards of the practice of veterinary medicine,

in the case of an authorized agent acting under section 12 of the Act, the authorized agent does so in accordance with the directions of a registered veterinarian or the guidelines referred to in paragraph (c), or

in any other case, the person does so in accordance with the guidelines set out in "Guidelines for euthanasia of domestic animals by firearms" by J. (Al) Longair, et al., published in Volume 32 of the Canadian Veterinary Journal in December, 1991, beginning at page 724.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who kills a sled dog must ensure that all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: death must occur quickly, and without unnecessary pain, suffering or distress;
if death is not apparent immediately on attempting to kill the sled dog, a second attempt must be made immediately;
other persons and animals are protected from physical and psychological harm during the killing process.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that a sled dog is dead before leaving the sled dog's body.
An operator must keep records that permit ready identification of each sled dog, including

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the sled dog's photograph, name, sex, breed and distinctive markings, and
if any, the sled dog's registration, microchip or tattoo number.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must keep all of the following records in respect of each sled dog:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the sled dog's birth date and date of death, if known;
if the operator acquired the sled dog after its birth, the date on which the operator acquired the sled dog;
if the operator disposed of the sled dog before its death, the date on which the operator disposed of the sled dog, including the manner of disposition;
the records required under sections 8 (2) (a) and 21 (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must keep all of the following health records in respect of each sled dog:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: records stating each date the sled dog was weighed, and the sled dog's weight on that date;
vaccination and deworming records;
records respecting all surgical procedures;
records respecting all illnesses or injuries, other than illnesses or injuries that are trivial in nature;
records of all known and suspected drug or food allergies;
if applicable, records respecting the breeding and whelping of the sled dog.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an operator was the person responsible for a sled dog when it died, the operator must keep a record of the cause of death and the manner and location of the disposition of the sled dog's body.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator must prepare, for each sled dog, a life cycle plan substantially in the form set out in Schedule C.
A person who contravenes any of sections 3 to 11, 12 (1), 13, 14 (2) or (3), 15 to 17, 18 (1) or 19 to 23 commits an offence.
